body:
@dmathieu here's something you can run:

```ruby
acronym = "API"
100.times { ActiveSupport::Inflector.inflections.acronym acronym.next!.dup }
class ActiveSupport::Inflector::Inflections
  def acronym_regex2
    @acronym_regex2 ||= /#{@acronyms.values.join("|")}/
  end
end
ActiveSupport::Inflector.inflections.instance_exec do
  Benchmark.bmbm do |x|
    x.report("acronym_regex") { 10_000_000.times { acronym_regex } }
    x.report("acronym_regex2") { 10_000_000.times { acronym_regex2 } }
  end
end
```
gives:

```
Rehearsal --------------------------------------------------
acronym_regex    2.020000   0.000000   2.020000 (  2.011851)
acronym_regex2   3.530000   0.000000   3.530000 (  3.533895)
----------------------------------------- total: 5.550000sec

                     user     system      total        real
acronym_regex    2.000000   0.000000   2.000000 (  2.005268)
acronym_regex2   3.530000   0.000000   3.530000 (  3.528883)
```

The 75% slowdown shouldn't be surprising. However, at this level, the impact on overall Rails performance is so low that it's not worth quibbling about. If implementing the method as a conditional set is what it takes to get this patch accepted, then I'd do it.
